context.speaker: Richard J. Connor
context.text: However we'd again be met with the problem that we seem to be run into – run into here, we don't know whether the Commission would let us sell that chunk of gas to Con Edison for boiler fuels despite the fact that it was selling best amounts of sort of combination gas or regular CD gas, a large part of which goes under their boilers.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Isn't there another problem that it is raised by the question just put by Justice Stewart?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If the only reason from withholding the certificate was that there was a sale -- a sale or no resale purchase, then it might be argued that the denial of the certificate means they're going to use the certificating power in order to prevent -- to prevent what otherwise are non-regulatable sale, non-sale research.

context.speaker: Richard J. Connor
context.text: That is precisely the point, Your Honor.

Federal Power Commission v. Transcontine.speaker: Justice Frankfurter

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann
context.text: Now --

context.text: Pardon?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann

Gallagher v. Crown Kosher Super Market o.speaker: Justice Harlan

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann
context.text: You drive along in the summer time there you can't throw a rock without hitting the shoreline, a -- a place that would sell steamed clams to the passerby.

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann
context.text: It is true that it can be done by -- by an amateur such as myself occasionally, but it's a commercial operation and sea clams are dredged just as oysters are dredged and not only are they dredged but they're seeded and this is a big business in Massachusetts, the seeding of clams.

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann
context.text: So that this attempt to explain that the digging of clams is alright because of some idea that people -- individual people like to do it, comes back to an a -- the only agreement that I know between Mr. Elcock and myself on some of the fundamentals of this case.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan II
context.text: But on your establishment of religious -- religious points, don't you ultimately, have to face up to the question that Justice Black put to you, namely whether the State has got power to pass a day of rest statute? Because surely, our duty in construing a state statute, granted everything that you say, is to save this statute if we can do it and therefore, it seems to me, you'll have to face up to that basic question as to whether the State has got the -- has got the right to prescribe a day of rest.

context.speaker: Herbert B. Ehrmann
context.text: Well, I suppose we will run into that.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan II
context.text: I don't see how you can avoid it.

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: We're not asking to -- to overrule Colegrove versus Green.

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: Our contention is that this is not a reapportionment case and that the Colegrove doctrine has nothing to do with the problems which are raised here.

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: We take the position that this is purely a race discrimination case and that it is not involved in the Colegrove versus Green problem at all.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Carter, suppose I go on with Justice Black's hypothetical case, an existing county happens to natural coagulation, to a natural aggregation to have predominantly in one half of it white, said reduced and then in the other half, colored city and the State then splits it into half but each half continues to have voting right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Nothing is done to -- to takeaway the -- either directly or to any manipulating of the electoral machinery, to potentiality or the opportunity for the exercise of the franchise.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What will you do with that case?

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: A simple question of drawing lines that -- that territory that was watched within certain limits, metes and bounds and now no longer there.

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: The metes and bounds are different, and they are different because of people that have a rights to draw or drew.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Mr. Carter, if you were here in this lawsuit formally to admit purpose, to be as allege.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: You'd have then, would you not, the same situation as hypothesized by Mr. Justice Harlan?

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: Yes, sir, I probably would.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: But the question as you raised now is that there can be no proper proof of motive.

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: Of course Your Honor to ask that and well-pleaded though, you must to have something that's susceptible of proof and relevancy.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Well, that's your point?

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But Mr. Carter your answer to Justice Harlan's question, makes into a general proposition that you are standing on an absence.

context.speaker: James J. Carter
context.text: I am.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Suppose -- suppose the Legislature of Alabama said, whereas these people of the United States has said and then quoted the thing you quote from Laramie County, from Beckwith, from Hunter and Pittsburgh.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: But you then come down to the hard-core of the man-to-man relationship between one human being who was passing judgment on another and it's not such a burdensome requirement that it -- it seems to make much sense to say, "Well, that's not important that counsel can do it for him."

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: That doesn't hold up the process of just as much for the judge to put the question right to the defendant rather than assuming that he has nothing he could say.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Vorenberg, I suppose there's no way that you could know how -- how usual it is or how unusual it is for -- for a district judge to give the defendant personally an opportunity to exercise this right, as you say -- say should be given.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, Mr. Justice Whittaker said -- indicated his practice on this district judge, you had no way a copy of that (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: I -- I'd just be guessing if I spoke on that except for one -- one point, Your Honor.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: I refer in my brief two hearings before the House of Representatives Committee on the Judiciary.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: And to me, the -- the balance is so heavily in favor of according this right.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: I mean its -- it requires such a small ritual of the -- of the trial judge.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: And it is -- there is so much at stake on the other side that I can't see any strong argument against it.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I don't see why you're having trouble with Mr. Justice Whittaker on the question under your statement.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: If a lawyer says he wants him to stop, I actually think your answer would be the lawyer can't stop him.

context.speaker: James Vorenberg
context.text: Cannot stop him.

context.text: But they also did discuss and gave the Court of Appeals at least as much insight and -- into the issue that they raised in terms of the facts and the various propositions involved in it, the only error they made and this -- I think it points up at the very meaning of the Ellis case as this Court opinion demonstrate.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: The error that they made and I think the error that the Court of Appeals here made was that having had this amount of insight given to them into the issue, it was resolved by this appointed counsel and by the Court of Appeals which already in that case in terms of the merit.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But I think that -- I think a court reading on the -- reading a record which Justice Whittaker just add on this, outlined delineated, a court power or room of action is very different from counsel appointed to defend a person and conceiving himself to be a lay judge.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Those are very different function.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: That is true, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You said certainly this second question, are you suggesting we should decide the second question in case that goes against it that goes for you as an end of the matter, isn't true?

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Well, that is true.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: If you --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If it goes for you, are you then suggesting we should send the case back to the Court of Appeals on that, what Mr. Justice Whittaker has categorized, as a frivolous question?

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Well, no, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Let me --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, no.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But if it goes against you --

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: If it goes against me --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- will you suggest that -- that we should send the -- the evidentiary question part which Mr. Justice Whittaker has expressed not only his own views, do you think we should send that back to the Court of Appeals?

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Well, I think that that is -- has not been resolved properly at the Court of Appeals level.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: I don't think that they properly apply the Ellis standard to that issue.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Davis, before you proceed, (Inaudible) the metaphysical question, they're all friends of mine.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I should like to put this to you -- I should like to ask you nearly by way of getting elucidation.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: On the assumption, the ninth point that's made that granted the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals is a constitutional court now.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But Justice Jackson's retirement preceded that enactment.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Therefore, he is in the constitutional.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: He isn't -- he has a constitutional status.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But now, I'm just wondering, if that was the University of Ohio, the State University of Ohio, it wasn't, as I recall it, but if it had been, would those people have been guilty of violating this law?

context.speaker: Gertrude Bauer Mahon
context.text: I believe, Mr. Justice, that the law is directed against a scienter possession.

context.speaker: Gertrude Bauer Mahon
context.text: By your very definition in the Roth case, a scienter possession for this purpose -- well, I guess the Roth case, again you have a — and I say under the law there is a difference between a lawful and an unlawful possession.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, the only question I'd be interested in having you answer is the one that Mr. Justice Frankfurter asked you earlier in your argument.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: If there is anything in this statute or in the interpretation that your Supreme Court has made of that statute which differentiates, let us say, between possession of these materials by a housewife on the one hand, and by, let us say, the university of some state on the other hand, for scientific purposes?

context.speaker: Gertrude Bauer Mahon
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: I think this is the kind of thing that is peculiarly within the control of the defendant and that if he can explain it away he is obligated to do so.

context.speaker: William David Dexter
context.text: We --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black

context.text: I -- I understood you in answer to Justice Frankfurter to say that this Court had held in several cases, the state to carry out a policy to encourage the little (Inaudible) instead of lack of (Inaudible) by making tax rates differ?

context.speaker: William David Dexter
context.text: This is not -- this is -- I -- I'm sorry.

context.speaker: William David Dexter
context.text: The -- the policy I have referred to was what is called the partial exemption rule, Your Honor.

context.speaker: J. Hubbard Davis
context.text: Right, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And then the Court of the Appeals set aside one of them.

context.speaker: J. Hubbard Davis
context.text: They vacated --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I -- I don't get the course of your answer to Justice Douglas' question, other than to take care of the situation.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It wouldn't take care of the situation if the jury had to determine the sentence.

context.speaker: J. Hubbard Davis
context.text: But we feel that had the jury been so instructed that they could only find the defendants guilty as a principal or as a receiver.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: It could have done either, couldn't he?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I don't -- I don't understand your argument here, that's why you say it couldn't have left the other in effect.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The jury could have found either way.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: It's was Justice Frankfurter, suggested they couldn't be as capricious as they desire, if that caprice.

context.text: The jury can be capricious, we may assume as to its finding of facts, but after it has found the fact and found both of the --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Wrongfully -- wrongfully under the law.

context.speaker: J. F. Bishop
context.text: Well, in any of --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: J. F. Bishop
context.text: Pardon?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- isn't -- the question of Justice Black as what the real question, namely, our duty with reference to what the Court of Appeals did.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And we say, the Court of Appeals on this record, misinterpreted the provision of the sentence.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Out of an independent judge or what we think ought to be done on the record.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Within the four corners of this statute, could that distinction be drawn?

context.text: Well, let -- let me show Your Honor the legislative history and I think this is overwhelming as to what Congress intended.

context.text: That I think this man has been tried, has been biting at the apple since 1956, trying to get out --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But can a defendant -- can a prisoner reject the advice of -- assume this, assume, assume that due process does impose upon the States the duty to supply a lawyer to an indigent -- indigently convicted defendant in a capital case and otherwise, you'll have the situation as you're having here, with all the hypotheses in fact, in the record, which Justice Stewart had put to you.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Assume all that, can the defendant say, "I reject the advise of my lawyers and I would like -- I think, I have a chance," but would he be barred by the -- not only the honest and contentious, but the wise advice of lawyers and go on his own?

context.speaker: Reno S. Harp, III
context.text: I would say that he would be barred, but there's one factor that I think, Your Honor left out of that question that I should like to supply if I may, because we ran into this very situation, not two months ago, with a habeas corpus case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: At best one can argue one way or the other is to write that opinion of his presupposes whether he did or didn't assume that this man was indigent.

context.speaker: Reno S. Harp, III
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: We have before us, the underlying documents.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Maybe the two letters to which Justice Black referred to them a while ago.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What do you say may this Court, in the situation which we find ourselves, make an independent judgment and conclude that those letters are if not an ignorant man, in elegant way of expressing the fact the he doesn't have a lawyer, because he hasn't got the money to hire one, to pay one.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is -- is it open to this Court to make an independent judgment.

context.speaker: Armistead L.boothe

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Armistead L.boothe

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Armistead L.boothe

context.text: Now, it seems to me the Court could -- never have viewed the case the way it did if it had thought that the incitement standard was applicable.

context.speaker: John J. Abt

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: John J. Abt

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And if I may pursue just one question farther then, when a man goes before the grand jury under an order of this kind, he gets immunity under any answer that he makes unless the prosecutor says, now, I've finished with this matter that -- that was referred to -- to me here by the order of the court and I now want to pursue counterfeiting or something else as Justice Frankfurter has -- has said.

context.text: Up until that time, any question with the prosecutor asked and he answers immunizing him?

context.text: Well, I -- I don't --

context.speaker: Theodore George Gilinsky

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, the only thing I had is unless the prosecutor says "Now, we're through with that business and we'll now go on to something detached -- totally detached from it, to wit, counterfeiting and -- and man act and other -- other crimes that we might mention.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If a man is before a grand jury, the grand jury having the function that this Court has described not so long ago in opinion by Justice Black and a -- a witness is contumacious or refuses to answer because he thinks he has constitutional right, he's then brought before the Court and the United States Attorney makes the presentation and the judge then said, “Well, I'll grant you immunity, you'll go back and answer.”

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It was simple and it's conclusive and comprehensive as all that.

context.speaker: Melvin B.lewis
context.text: If it -- if it please the Court, I would -- I would suggest to Your Honor that it would be a virtual impossibility for a witness before a grand jury, a year after his appearance there to show that, in fact, he had answered a given question in response into an -- to an inquiry put to him by a prosecutor before that grand jury after first having claimed his constitutional immunity in that field.

context.speaker: Richard F. Levy
context.text: And here, they said that petitioner had not stated the cause of action and that as a matter of fact, it was not even open to petitioner under the complaint to prove the unreasonableness under the circumstances because there is no allegation in the complaint that the AGA did not have a good reason for denying the seal of approval, in other words, that there was no allegation in their view that the seal was denied arbitrarily and capriciously.

context.speaker: Richard F. Levy
context.text: And this -- this was the extent of their inquiry under the rule of reason.Finally, the Court of Appeals said there was no cause of action here because the complaint failed to allege injury to the public in the form, and I think this important, in the form of an appreciable lessening in the sale of conversion gas burners or that the public has been deprived of a product of overall superiority.

context.speaker: Richard F. Levy
context.text: In other words, no public injury because we didn't say that our product was not merely as good as but overall superior to all the other products on the market, and we didn't have a cause of action because there was no appreciable lessening in the sale of gas burners.

context.speaker: Charles A. Horsky
context.text: It seems to me, I can -- I think I stated it rather summarily yesterday.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Now, when the Government had to prove, in this case, the Communist Party was a party which was dedicated to the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, obviously, the written materials, the constitution, the foundations of Leninism, the basic text of the Communist Party would be the same.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: We don't discover new basic documents in the Communist Party.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: The basic documents which were introduced in this case were the same as the basic documents that were introduced in Yates.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: As I understand it, from what you answered to Justice Frankfurter, your position is that if you show that a man is a member of a party which has an illegal aim, and he knows about it and believes in it, and works for the Party, he can be prosecuted for his membership in that Party.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Mr. Justice Black, I don't mean to evade you.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: I don't know whether you, in using the term “a member,” whether you said an active member.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: This, I think, is merely a question -- I -- I mean it's a questions of definition.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: What is active in other words?

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: And my -- my suggestion is that any affirmative, and I use the word "act", I don't' know what else to use, any affirmative act which is made which he performs as a part -- as -- as a member, acquire member rather than as someone else, will sufficient to make him an active member.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I'll get back to Justice Frankfurter's question, paying of dues?

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Paying of dues most certainly.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And that's enough?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Following up --

context.speaker: Herschel H. Friday Jr.
context.text: -- we could assume many things.

context.speaker: Herschel H. Friday Jr.
context.text: I think certainly, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Following up Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question, is what I had in mind.

context.speaker: Herschel H. Friday Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Is this, if it be true that this is broad enough to require revelations and divulsions of organizations in which he belonged, it might subject him to the harassment.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: I would hope that, in reversing this case, it would overrule Olmsted but this is distinguishable because, here, there is a trespass even within the comprehension of Goldman and Olmsted.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: In the -- in the Olmsted case, they had physical contact with a wire, but the wire was much removed from the premises occupied by Olmsted.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: It was a -- a telephone wire in the basement of a large apartment house, not in his unit.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In answer to Justice Harlan, you were concerned merely with the ear.

context.text: What about the eye?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What about visual?

context.text: I'm sorry?

context.speaker: John M. Harlan II

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But I think you have to meet Justice Harlan's question beyond the answer that you gave because, as you suggest, Congress tomorrow might provide for authorization for a search warrant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And, there, it was a problem with the constitutionality of such law (Inaudible) authorization.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Just go beyond --

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And, one -- one consents -- on amendment is enough in order to try this.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If that is true, then how do you differentiate the case put by Justice Harlan, whether have an issue of the warrant for snooping purposes or merely for confirmatory of cumulative evidence? Why do you make a distinction?

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: I make this distinction for this reason, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: As I understand, the Fourth Amendment guaranteed the right of the people to be secure in their homes against unreasonable searches and seizures, but a necessary qualification of that right was that warrants might issue on probable cause to conduct a reasonable search and seizure.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: And, I think that when the founding fathers wrote the Fourth Amendment into the American Bill of Rights, it was in this frame of reference and they never intended that officers of the law should be given ingress into the home of private citizens so that they could fair about in a search for evidence of crime.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: I don't believe that, and so I say that if the Congress should pass such an Act authorizing warrants to issue or this kind of a search, that there would be a grave constitutional question which would be presented to this Court, notwithstanding the existence of the statute.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: This is my belief, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, if that's your view, then the short answer to Justice Harlan's question, if I may say so, in your point of view is that if Congress couldn't authorize it, it couldn't be done without authorization.

context.speaker: Edward Bennett Williams
context.text: It's --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I think for snooping for -- concerning snooping or whatnot.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: He and his earing -- hearing aid pick up the sounds outside of rather than within the protected premises.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Well, if this is the law, and if it stands up until this case, then the question really comes down to whether or not electronic devices have developed to such a stage or the practice of electronic snooping has developed to such an extent that this Court now feels that it's necessary that this law should be changed.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: And, I suggest that, in making a determination of that kind, it should be based upon what we have before us and it shouldn't be based upon some type of electronic devices which are mysteriously -- described in -- in some other context.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Davis, may I ask you the question that Mr. Justice Harlan asked Mr. Williams?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you make any distinction so far as this right that you're talking about now in the police officers between the situation where they're just going around generally and listening into people's homes or the situation where -- on the other hand, where they suspect that maybe there's something going on illegally in there?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you make any distinction or do you say that all of them are --

context.speaker: Luther L. Hill, Jr.
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Luther L. Hill, Jr.
context.text: Not habeas corpus where a wife is attempting to gain custody of children taken by the husband or something like that.

context.speaker: Luther L. Hill, Jr.
context.text: This is the distinction --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But there are instances as Justice Stewart has indicated, there are procedural reasons for the distinction Tom Tong or such a case where the Court had to decide whether it was a final judgment, whether there was a final judgment or whether a certification was allowed by a divided court alone, if it was -- if the case couldn't come here on certification which said merely in criminal proceeding, that was there, the purposes of having direct review.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So that the determination of whether it was civil or criminal and that in Tom Tong, it's quite unrelated to this problem.

context.speaker: Luther L. Hill, Jr.
context.text: And as I think Justice Stewart pointed out, there are other consequences that flow, the time governance and so forth.

context.text: First -- first reversal.

context.text: Yes, sir.

context.text: I don't find in -- anything from (c) to (h) an allegation in the form that Mr. Justice Whittaker put it to you, namely, an allegation that negligence in the manner of conducting (Inaudible).

context.text: Well, Judge, I can only read to you, "In negligently failing to provide the plaintiff with proper equipment and safeguards in performance of his duties and in the participation in such a field test."

context.text: At the end of the case which under Florida law was sufficient, those --

context.text: Mr. Wahl.

context.speaker: Harold B. Wahl
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Justice Whittaker asked you whether you could read allegations (a) and (b) under paragraph (5) as alleging negligence in regard to the manner in which the test was pursued.

context.speaker: Harold B. Wahl
context.text: I said no, just as emphatically as I know how to say it --

context.speaker: Edward L. Carey
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Edward L. Carey
context.text: I would say in answer to that, no, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Edward L. Carey
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, then the --

context.speaker: Edward L. Carey
context.text: It was an intent --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm asking the question that Justice Stewart asked and Justice Whittaker asked.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Was the -- were there really any contest over the commission of a homicide?

context.speaker: Edward L. Carey

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: There is a provision on the contract which has not been stressed by petitioner, the reason I'll come to, to the effect that 15% of the buyers' requirements at any kind maybe supplied by byproduct fuels supplied by any costumer.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: In other words Tampa Electric reserve to itself the opportunity to take 15% of its requirements in the form of byproduct fuel if and when such was furnished to Tampa Electric by any of its costumers.

context.text: Now, Mr. Justice Stewart, number one you will note that that does not contemplate getting coal from anybody else.

context.text: Number two, this is so far as it appears in the record, from this years, it's purely theoretical possibility that perhaps sometime --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now note, the record, as the record here indicates it is no simple matter to turn from coal to oil in an electric utility plant.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: They themselves say that it cost them $3 million to construct coal burning facilities here at Gannon then if they had used oil.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Note number two that as petitioner states in -- in its reply brief which is in clear statement of it, the offer of Peabody Coal was rejected and they never went -- they never accepted that offer, so that the situation remains entirely theoretical.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I may say Mr. Justice that the mere possibility that someone may use another fuel as I was coming through later in my argument does not lift a contract from a requirement's contract into something less than a requirements contract as Mr. Justice Frankfurter noted in the opinion for the Court in Standard Oil, the requirements contracts there replied only to particular stations and it was urged that the contracting buy might get another station which would not be bound by the exclusive contract which stand at all -- I'm willing what the Court concluded that that was a no matter.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Similarly in the Standard Fashion case which is sort of the grand daddy and one of the ancestors in this field, the exclusive contract there covered the sail of patents to buyers on -- at their particular stores, their particular premises.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It was there said just as petitioner here says, well, if I may have another story says we may have another plant to use coal and at that other store in the Standard Fashion we may buy some patents from somebody else.

Tampa Electric Company v. Nashville Coal.case_name: Tampa Electric Company v. Nashville Coal Company

context.speaker: Abe Fortas

context.text: Mr. Fortas, you seem to find some importance in the provision of the contract of another coal burning facility might have been in the future be erected by Standard and that -- and that the requirement provision would be tied to the new facility.

context.text: My question is whether that the record shows that that was an incipient enterprise or that was also just another that's been given (Inaudible) provisions in the contract.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It shows more than that Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Actually as the record shows, a third unit was actually constructed to burn coal and was under the contract.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You mean after the contract had been --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now, your question to me is whether the competitor -- whether a contract would still meet the qualifying clause if it were for a new commodity introduced into a particular community.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I believe I state that forever.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That is precisely one of the considerations considered in the Standard Oil case.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter's opinion for the Court there and rejected in that case as something that Congress did not have in mind in terms of Section 3, and I think properly so and let me, if I may, elaborate that.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, the easiest thing in the world to do in many commercial situations as every lawyer knows is entered into requirements contracts.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: The requirements contracts makes everybody feel nice and secured, but what it does is to remove a whole area of our economy from competition pro tanto with the requirements contracts.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Mr. Chanler wants this Court to rule that this -- a contract does not violate Section 3 unless the seller has economic leverage sufficient to impose the condition.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now I thought that was all settled.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It's very interesting, Mr. Chanler in his principal brief here for the petitioner didn't mention Times-Picayune although we have briefed it below, it came rather toward only in his reply brief.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: But in Times-picayune, this Court very, which was a Sherman Act case, this Court very carefully delineated the distinction in this respect between the Sherman Act and the Clayton Act, and I want to quote Mr. Justice Black's opinion for the Court.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: From the tying cases, perceptible pattern emerges.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Under the Clayton Act if the seller enjoys a monopolistic position in the market for the tying product, or, and that is underlined in the opinion, or a substantial volume of commerce in the tied product is restrained, the arrangement violates the narrower standards of Section 3.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: If the Court will kindly turn to page two of our brief, this grey brief, we have set forth the statute and I'm sure the Court is familiar with it but I want to call the attention of a few particulars in the statute.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It should be unlawful for any person to lease or make a sale or contract for sale or use consumption or a resale on the condition agreement or understanding that the lessee or purchaser, note the single bearer shall not use or deal in the goods, wares, merchandise, machinery, commodities etcetera of a competitor or competitors.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: In this, there's no question.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: But that that language includes a single contract was intended to include a single contract and if anyone chooses to enter the maze of legislative history here despite the Court's -- this Court's admonition of the contrary in the Standard Fashions case, I am sure he must conclude that the Congress intended to reach a contract in a town as Mr. Justice Frankfurter has pointed out in the Standard Oil and as is shown in the legislative history.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: In the good year of 1914, good in some respects, the Congress was very much concerned about antitrust.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It was very much concerned about monopoly.
